title: Hey Texans!  Texas Independence Day is March 2

content: quote: Originally posted by stillkit: DAMMIT! I have simply GOT to remember the difference between the quote button and the edit button! As a Mod, I can click both of them and it's causing me problems! Because of my stupidity, I just deleted a post by someone (I think it was Mom), when I didn't intend to. I'd responded to her post about SE Texas, around Beaumont, being partial to crawfish and, when I realized I'd accidently hit the edit button instead of the quote, I saved my comments and deleted the rest. Well, heck...that deleted her entire post! DAMMIT! I'm sorry, Mom or whoever you were, I really didn't do that on purpose. Here's my response to you. Yeah, I know, but Texas east of Winnie and south of Woodville is more Louisiana than Texas and you know it. They're all johnny-come-lately's brought here by the Spindletop boom. The REAL Texas, and real TEXAN'S, consider crawdads as bait. R E A L ?????!!!!!! Texans?? Hey Kit....you better watch out! Someone may take a swing at you like the little old Lady with the frying pan! Actually it was my response that you took out. I was responding to your comment about crayfish, crawfish, mudbugs... And you seem to be a bit mixed up.....spindletop didn't come into until 1901. Beaumont originated from Neches River Settlement (1824)when Nancy and Noah Tevis had a farm there. Then it developed into a farming community (and Beaumont 1835). As I mentioned in my post, we enjoyed living for a number of years down there in SE Texas (Beaumont area and ate lots of crawfish) especially at Mardi Gras time. BTW your area (if I recall correctly) came about much later due to the railroads and developed later in the 1840s. Unless you are talking about Kentucky Town which was the first area people came to in G county (1837). But you did make me hungry for some of the deep SE TX food! Found this, which you will enjoy! A book called "Eats" "http://books.google.com/books?id=Knu0Xn2iJb4C&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=Texas+cooking+%2B+crawfish+%2B+history&source=bl&ots=2Og-Jo8sTf&sig=KI_67WjCW-w8HPOLpP9jpkhbEoY&hl=en&ei=ureqSbjeIMTAnQf99LzVDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPR14,M1" "They love our milk and honey but they preach about some other way of living When you’re running down my country, Hoss you’re walking on the fighting side of me" - - Merle Haggard
quote: Originally posted by stillkit: DAMMIT! I have simply GOT to remember the difference between the quote button and the edit button! Yeah, I know, but Texas east of Winnie and south of Woodville is more Louisiana than Texas and you know it. They're all johnny-come-lately's brought here by the Spindletop boom. The REAL Texas, and real TEXAN'S, consider crawdads as bait.

Beaumont originated from Neches River Settlement (1824)when Nancy and Noah Tevis had a farm there. Then it developed into a farming community (and Beaumont 1835). content: quote: Originally posted by aggie_swife: Okay, what are you going to do to celebrate? Many places are celebrating on March 1st --- good music at Love n War in Texas (Plano). They are even having a crawfish boil! Better enjoy it, before the Alamo gets reconquista'd Wandering and Wondering
quote: Originally posted by aggie_swife: Okay, what are you going to do to celebrate? Many places are celebrating on March 1st --- good music at Love n War in Texas (Plano). They are even having a crawfish boil!
reply: Better enjoy it, before the Alamo gets reconquista'd Wandering and Wondering

A book called "Eats" "http://books.google.com/books?id=Knu0Xn2iJb4C&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=Texas+cooking+%2B+crawfish+%2B+history&source=bl&ots=2Og-Jo8sTf&sig=KI_67WjCW-w8HPOLpP9jpkhbEoY&hl=en&ei=ureqSbjeIMTAnQf99LzVDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPR14,M1" "They love our milk and honey but they preach about some other way of living When you’re running down my country, Hoss you’re walking on the fighting side of me" - - Merle Haggard
title: Hey Texans!  Texas Independence Day is March 2

title: Hey Texans!  Texas Independence Day is March 2

content: quote: Originally posted by aggie_swife: quote: Originally posted by stillkit: DAMMIT! I have simply GOT to remember the difference between the quote button and the edit button! As a Mod, I can click both of them and it's causing me problems! Because of my stupidity, I just deleted a post by someone (I think it was Mom), when I didn't intend to. I'd responded to her post about SE Texas, around Beaumont, being partial to crawfish and, when I realized I'd accidently hit the edit button instead of the quote, I saved my comments and deleted the rest. Well, heck...that deleted her entire post! DAMMIT! I'm sorry, Mom or whoever you were, I really didn't do that on purpose. Here's my response to you. Yeah, I know, but Texas east of Winnie and south of Woodville is more Louisiana than Texas and you know it. They're all johnny-come-lately's brought here by the Spindletop boom. The REAL Texas, and real TEXAN'S, consider crawdads as bait. R E A L ?????!!!!!! Texans?? Hey Kit....you better watch out! Someone may take a swing at you like the little old Lady with the frying pan! Actually it was my response that you took out. I was responding to your comment about crayfish, crawfish, mudbugs... And you seem to be a bit mixed up.....spindletop didn't come into until 1901. Beaumont originated from Neches River Settlement (1824)when Nancy and Noah Tevis had a farm there. Then it developed into a farming community (and Beaumont 1835). As I mentioned in my post, we enjoyed living for a number of years down there in SE Texas (Beaumont area and ate lots of crawfish) especially at Mardi Gras time. BTW your area (if I recall correctly) came about much later due to the railroads and developed later in the 1840s. Unless you are talking about Kentucky Town which was the first area people came to in G county (1837). But you did make me hungry for some of the deep SE TX food! Found this, which you will enjoy! A book called "Eats" "http://books.google.com/books?id=Knu0Xn2iJb4C&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=Texas+cooking+%2B+crawfish+%2B+history&source=bl&ots=2Og-Jo8sTf&sig=KI_67WjCW-w8HPOLpP9jpkhbEoY&hl=en&ei=ureqSbjeIMTAnQf99LzVDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPR14,M1" Yeah, I know that Beaumont was there before Spindletop, but it was the oil boom which brought the Cajuns to that part of Texas.
